slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to Module One: Introduction to College Advising

The topics in this module include:

•An introduction to College Advising

•The History of College Advising

•The Role of the College Advisor

Please note, for this module, we will be providing a counseling model. However, this model can also be useful for all types of professionals working with students.

International Baccalaureate (IB)

The IB is a non-profit educational organization that provides programs for international education that focus on intellectual, personal, and social growth. The IB Diploma Program is for students within ages 16 to 19, in the United States and aboard, and provides a framework for rigor and innovation to challenge students and deepen their knowledge of the world. Students use reflection, complete an independent project, and conduct community service. Some colleges will allot students college credit for their IB classes. Of note, many high schools will offer IB curriculum as well as College Board AP courses.

Magnet Programs

Magnet schools are public schools that attract highly competitive students from across a region through an application process.

Public, Private, and Charter Schools

Public schools are institutions supported by public funds.

Private schools are supported by private individuals, organizations, and religious organizations.

Charter schools are typically defined as publicly funded independent schools that can be created by teachers, parents, or community members.
What do you think are the purposes of college advising? Select all that apply

Students from under-represented groups often enroll in two-year institutions and less selective and resourced four-year colleges, placing these students at an even greater disadvantage. What do you think the reasons might be? Select all that apply.

Click the time periods and programs to learn more about them.

19th and 20th Century

Social Events during the 19th and 20th centuries contributed to a strong emphasis placed on vocational counseling. Events such as:

•Industrial Revolution

•World War I

•Great Depression

•World War II

During this time, it was important to distinguish among people because you had to know who had the skills to fly a plane or to fight in combat. The focus was on classifying people. There was a great emphasis on testing, like Intelligence measures including the IQ test. Tests helped measure intelligence to find individual differences so people could be classified.

1920s-1950s

Vocational counselors were often teachers who volunteered to assist students in entering the work world. The primary roles of counselors in schools during this time were to:

•“Sort” students into the appropriate work pathways.

•Encourage teachers to make connections between classroom content and occupations.

•Promote character development.

•Teach appropriate social behaviors.

•Assist with vocational planning.

There was little emphasis placed on academic remediation and going to college.

1950s

Given the lack of emphasis placed on college during the 1950s, there is significantly less information regarding college advising as it relates to school counseling. However, two things occurred. One was the National Defense Act of 1958 that heightened post-secondary education awareness. It provided funding to support secondary school counseling.

The second was the professional requirements for school counselors (known at the time as guidance counselors) also changed in the 1950s. The American Psychological Association (APA) and American Personnel and Guidance Association (APGA) established distinct standards and requirements for helping professionals, like psychologists and guidance counselors.

1970s-1980s

Beginning in the 1970s, education initiatives were geared toward preparing students for heightened academic achievement and post-secondary preparedness. One example, the High School That Works uses research-based strategies integrated into public education systems to facilitate students’ high academic achievement and emphasizes how education environments can impact students’ motivation towards achievement. However, during this time period, school counselors were being trained like mental health counselors, rather than how to guide students academically.

1990s

During the 1990s, an increased skepticism surrounded the need for college counseling and post-secondary advising. There was a stronger emphasis on self-help methods, students doing more on their own rather than with assistance of trained professional, which led to a downsize in federally funded opportunity programs.

This resulted in a drastic increase in:

•The achievement gap

•Drop-out rates

•Students failing exams

Source: Erford, B. T. (2015). Becoming a professional school counselor: Current perspectives, historical roots and future challenges. In B. T. Erford (Ed.), Transforming the school counseling profession (4th ed.)(pp. 1-28). Columbus, OH: Pearson Merrill.

Education Trust Impact

The Education Trust, an organization founded in the 1990s, sought to determine how to assist all students to succeed academically.

•Aimed to reduce the achievement gap

•Acknowledged that school counselors were not well-prepared to help with college access for all students

•Identified contextual barriers that prevented academic success for all students

•Contributed to the development of the ASCA National Model: A Framework for School Counseling Programs, created in 2003, the model provides school counselors and counseling teams with a framework to design, coordinate, implement, manage, and evaluate their programs for students’ success.

ASCA Model

Click each of the three parts of the model to learn more about it.

Transforming School Initiative

Transforming School Initiative aimed to redefine the focus of school counseling via changes to masters-level training preparation. Unlike their predecessors, who were trained in individual and small-group interventions intended for selected students, Transformed School Counselors were to understand persons, groups and organizations as complex systems that are embedded within a sociocultural context.

“…School counselors advocate for educational equity, access to a rigorous college and career-readiness curriculum, and academic success for all students” (Education Trust, 2012). It aimed to train school counselors in skills that are needed to remove barriers that impede student achievement (e.g., using data)

Alternative Programs

Despite the majority of college advising occurring in schools, scholars and professionals began to realize that:

•School counselors, who were functioning as academic advisors, schedulers and college advisors, had limited time to devote to each student’s individual needs

•Low-income students and students of color tended to be in high schools that failed to meet their post-secondary education needs

Alternative forms of college counseling began to emerge during the mid-20th century:

•Pre-Collegiate Outreach Programs

•Independent Educational Consultants

Click each alternative college advising program to learn more about it.
Click the buttons to read more about each of the college advisors roles.

College advisors need to:

Be aware of the history of guidance/counseling and social/political issues impacting future transformations. It is generally helpful to know where one has been when trying to know where one is going.

Use effective techniques and practices implemented through legal, ethical and professional means. This requires one to adhere to the highest standard outlined by the profession.

And, when applicable, maintain membership in professional organizations at the local, state and national levels.

. ASCA, ACA, and NACAC are the professional and political forces supporting the mission of professional school counselors at the national level

. Counselors have a responsibility to join and support the effort of these three professional organizations. Without doing so, the political and professional voices of school counselors will not be heard as loudly as other helping professions (e.g. , psychologists, social workers)

College Advisors must also be knowledgeable about different resources for themselves, other professionals, as well as students and their families throughout the college application process.

Please take some time to navigate and familiarize yourself with the following college advising websites, which can assist you in your future college advising role.
